pullRequest.title: Add missing similarity criteria between array and tuple types
pullRequest.bodyText:
Purpose

The type test expression when used with arrays and tuple types was producing incorrect outputs in several scenarios as mentioned here. This pull request fixes the mentioned issues.

Fixes #23676
Approach

Changing some of the logic in checkIsTupleType function and doing minor changes in the checkIsArrayType function of the TypeChecker class.

nodes.bodyText: additional parenthesis
seems theres a formatting issue here
better to do the memberTypesMatch check first. Then we can fail-fast
same as above
additional parenthesis
Shall we extract sourceTupleType.getRestType() out to a variable since it is used multiple times?
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -1242,32 +1247,45 @@ private static boolean checkIsArrayType(BType sourceType, BArrayType targetType,
                 tupleTypes.add(sourceTupleType.getRestType());

nodes.bodyText: Isn't this always true because we return at L1250?

Since the rest type is added to tupleTypes in L1247, isn't this checked already?
Why do we need to special case the sourceTupleType.getRestType() != null && targetType.getState() == ArrayState.OPEN scenario anyway?
Shouldn't we special case the scenario where the target type is a closed array instead? The following should pass, but doesn't atm.
    [int, ()] x = [1, ()];
    assertTrue(<any> x is (string|int?)[2]);
When the target array is open, can't we let the flow to continue by setting the proper state to sourceArrayType?
i.e.,

tuple type with no rest type - CLOSED
tuple type with rest type - OPEN
Can't we directly return false here instead of setting it to memberTypesMatch?
Check remainingMemberTypesMatch too.

Can you also add one like
    assertEquality(y is [int, int, string...], true);
Let's add similar checks for others too. e.g., testClosedArrayType

IMO, even though there seem to be some other tests related to array/tuple type tests here, these tests don't quite belong here. Shall we move them and the new tests to a type test expression test. e.g., org.ballerinalang.test.expressions.binaryoperations.TypeTestExprTest
IMO we can remove this special-casing, since checkIsType does pretty much the same.
Have we added tests for this? Where the source type is a union of lists?
Let's extract these two scenarios also to two methods.

Instead of adding the rest-descriptor to tupleTypes can we handle it separately?
For example,

if the target array is closed, the source cannot have a rest-descriptor (return false directly). If there is no rest-descriptor it may be valid, so check each member against the target array's element type - we seem to be doing this already
if the target array is open, check member types against element type, and then check the rest-descriptor against the target element type separately - add another check to the else block below

Shall we also add tests like
    assertEquality(b is [int, int...], true);

Since these are only used in L1267 we can move these to immediately before L1267 or just remove these and change that to
return checkIsType(sourceType.getElementType(), targetType.getElementType(), unresolvedTypes);
Do we need a new set here? Can't we just work with the list returned by sourceType.getTupleTypes()?
Here again, for both sourceTypes and targetTypes, since we are no longer adding the rest types to these lists we can directly use the lists returned by getTupleTypes() instead of creating new lists.
